    TODO: Test Incompatible SP exception for all these cases: - regular search path - a filter key which is a search path TODO: Test invalid nested target element value Created by QuijadaJ on 5/5/2017.

    • Method Detail

      • obtainJsonContext

        public void obtainJsonContext()

      • canSearch

        public void canSearch()

      • canSearchWithArrayElementInSearchPath

        public void canSearchWithArrayElementInSearchPath()
        Test capability to search for a specific entry of an array when the array is found in the last node of the search path. We test selecting array entries individually, and also selecting entire array, and in each instance then check the expected results are the only ones found.

      • canSearchWithArrayElementInSearchPathThatIsNotLastNode

        public void canSearchWithArrayElementInSearchPathThatIsNotLastNode()

      • nonFinalNodeWithoutBracketsThrowsExceptionWhenArrayEncountered

        public void nonFinalNodeWithoutBracketsThrowsExceptionWhenArrayEncountered()
        For nodes that are not the last one in the search path, tests that they contain square brackets if an array is expected in the JSON when that node is encountered. The reason for this check is that even though currently only getting the first array entry is supported ("[0]"), in future might add support to get something other than the first array entry.

      • canSearchUsingFilter

        public void canSearchUsingFilter()

      • canSearchUsingNestedFilter

        public void canSearchUsingNestedFilter()
        Test scenario where the search involves filtering on a field which is one or more level deeper than the located node.

      • canSelectFieldDeeperThanFoundNode

        public void canSelectFieldDeeperThanFoundNode()
        Test scenario where the search involves selecting from found node a field which is one or more levels deeper than found node.

      • selectSubsetOfElementsInFoundNode

        public void selectSubsetOfElementsInFoundNode()
        For a node in the JSON, select only a sub-set of the elements contained therein. This can be useful for instance when a rule is to be applied only to certain elements within an entity. Example: apply rule only to city and state fields of mailing address of a business entity.

      • searchUsingSelectionCriteriaObject

        public void searchUsingSelectionCriteriaObject()
        Ensure a SelectionCriteria string is correctly parsed, and search results are correct.

      • selectCorrectArrayEntryInSearchPath

        public void selectCorrectArrayEntryInSearchPath()
        Tests that the correct array entry is selected when the search path contains an array entry anywhere that is *not* the final node. Final node array test will be added later elsewhere.

      • searchReturnsArray

        public void searchReturnsArray()

      • filterNodeThatHasArrayMember

        public void filterNodeThatHasArrayMember()
        Test scenario when we're supposed to filter on an element which is an array of other complex structures, and the filter contains a name/value pair that corresponds to a member that's an array of primitives in the complex structures inside the found element array of complex structures. In such cases Context should be smart enough to compare the passed in a value to the entries contained in the actual array, and if there's a match, the complex structure node that contains such an array should be included in the search results.

      • filterArrayOfPrimitives

        public void filterArrayOfPrimitives()
        When the search path specifies an element which value is an array of primitives, test that the correct array entry is returned as per the filter argument passed by caller

      • filterUsingWildCard

        public void filterUsingWildCard()

      • searchWhenTargetFieldsAreRegularExpressions

        public void searchWhenTargetFieldsAreRegularExpressions()
        Test scenario where values in the target data should themselves be treated as regular expressions when evaluating search filters.

      • filterContainsList

        public void filterContainsList()
        Test filter contains a range of values

      • invalidFilterThrowsException

        public void invalidFilterThrowsException()
        Check that valid filter validation is taking place. We pass an filter which we know is not valid for the expected found element, and expect an IllegalArgumentException to be thrown.

      • searchResultIsComplexObject

        public void searchResultIsComplexObject()

      • canProduceContextFromXml

        public void canProduceContextFromXml()

      • produceContextForPrimitive

        public void produceContextForPrimitive()
        Simple test to get Context object primitive values.

      • contextObjectIsImmutable

        public void contextObjectIsImmutable()
        Tests that client cannot break the invariants of Context, which is supposed to be immutable. Thew test consists of creating a JsonElement, then using it to generate a Context, then updating the JsonElement that was used to create the Context, and finally check that Context object remained unchanged throughout.

      • invalidSearchPathValidations

        public void invalidSearchPathValidations()
        Checks that various invalid SearchPath related checks are working as expected. This includes: 1) Check that error is thrown if an array is found in a non-final search path node, yet it was not specified in the search path that an array node can be expected there. 2) Check that IncompatibleSearchPathException gets thrown when a bad search path is specified in these Context.findElement(SearchPath, Filter, TargetElements, Map) arguments: a) search path b) Filter c) Target elements We also test that above get ignored when appropriate flags get passed in the extra parameters Note: This is to test features that deal with JSON produced from XML, and sometimes the same field can appear as a single object, or an array of multiple objects, depending respectively on whether source XML contained single or multiple entries. It'd be nice for it always to be an array if it is array, even if only one single element found, but I suspect you'd need a JSON schema for that. So the workaround is to instruct API. The way this feature works is that by passing a flag in extra params, you can tell Context API to ignore error if a non-array is encountered in non final node.
